author: Oliver Smith
title: Tourists pet whales in remarkable drone video
text:
Tourists pet whales in remarkable drone video The wildlife photographer Mark Carwardine captured this dramatic footage off the coast of Baja California By Oliver Smith , video source Barcroft 10:16AM BST 05 Aug 2015 Comments 
A group of tourists had the close encounter of a lifetime off the coast of Baja California, Mexico, as this spectacular footage shows. 
The boat carrying the lucky party in the San Ignacio Lagoon was able to get near enough to a pod of four grey whales, including two young calves, that they were able to pat the majestic animals. 
The overhead shots were captured earlier this year by Mark Cawardine, the wildlife photographer, broadcaster and regular contributor to Telegraph Travel, using a drone. Other clips were taken used an underwater camera. 
In his guide to whale watching holidays , he writes: "You never forget your first whale. The impact it makes upon you is huge and life is never quite the same again. My first whale was a 40ft grey, off the coast of California in 1979, and I’ve been a whale addict ever since. Now I have to go whale watching at regular intervals just to survive normal daily life." 
Cawardine describes greys as the "friendliest" whale species and Baja California as "arguably the best whale watching destination in the world for sheer variety, with friendly grey whales in their breeding lagoons on the Pacific coast, singing humpback whales off the southern tip, and everything from blue whales to Bryde’s whales in the Sea of Cortez."
